question: If a mountain range contains mountains made of rocks and weathering can round rocks, what will happen to the shapes of the rocks in the mountain range over time?

content.source_1: A mountain range is a series of mountains made of solid rock, and those rocks are susceptible to mechanical and chemical weathering that break them into smaller particles.
content.source_2: Weathering produces sediment that is carried away by erosion; when tectonic uplift is minimal or absent, this removal of material lowers peak elevations and rounds the topography over long timescales.
content.source_3: Fluvial erosion tends to widen valleys and deposit sediment in adjacent basins, gradually producing gentler slopes and more subdued relief in aging mountain ranges.
content.source_4: In many orogenic belts, crustal thickening and tectonic uplift continue for millions of years after initial construction, and uplift can at times outpace erosional lowering.
content.source_5: As erosion removes mass from a range, isostatic rebound can raise the land surface, helping to maintain or even increase peak-to-valley relief despite ongoing mass loss.
content.source_6: Under cold-climate conditions, glacial erosion sharpens peaks into horns and carves deep U-shaped valleys and cirques, increasing ruggedness rather than smoothing the terrain.

answer: rounding the shapes of the rocks
